member.name: T:work.bacome.imapclient.cIMAPClient
member.summary: Instances of this class can interact with an IMAP server.

remarks.para: An instance may connect many times, possibly to different servers, but it can only be connected to one server at a time.
To connect to a server use . Before calling set and at a minimum. Also consider setting .
This class implements , so you should dispose instances when you are finished with them.

member.summary: Gets and sets the network-write batch-size configuration. You might want to limit this to increase the speed with which you can terminate the instance. May only be set while .

member.summary: Gets and sets the idle configuration. May be .

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cIMAPClient.AppendStreamReadConfiguration
member.summary: Gets and sets the default append-stream-read batch-size configuration. You might want to limit this to increase the speed with which you can terminate the instance.
member.remarks: Limits the size of the buffer when reading from the client-side stream (e.g. when reading an attachment from local disk). Measured in bytes. The default value is min=1000b, max=1000000b, maxtime=10s, initial=1000b.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cIMAPClient.FetchCacheItemsConfiguration
member.summary: Gets and sets the fetch-cache-items batch-size configuration. You might want to limit this to increase the speed with which you can cancel the fetch.
member.remarks: Limits the number of messages per batch when requesting cache-items from the server. Measured in number of messages. The default value is min=1 message, max=1000 messages, maxtime=10s, initial=1 message.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cIMAPClient.FetchBodyReadConfiguration
member.summary: Gets and sets the fetch-body-read batch-size configuration. You might want to limit this to increase the speed with which you can cancel the fetch.
member.remarks: Limits the size of the partial fetches used when getting body sections from the server. Measured in bytes. The default value is min=1000b, max=1000000b, maxtime=10s, initial=1000b.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cIMAPClient.FetchBodyWriteConfiguration
member.summary: Gets and sets the fetch-body-write batch-size configuration. You might want to limit this to increase the speed with which you can cancel the fetch.
member.remarks: Limits the size of the buffer when writing to the client-side stream (e.g. when writing to the local disk). Measured in bytes. The default value is min=1000b, max=1000000b, maxtime=10s, initial=1000b.

member.name: M:work.bacome.imapclient.cIMAPClient.Connect
member.summary: Connects to the using the . May only be called when the instance . Will throw if an authenticated IMAP connection cannot be established.

remarks.para: TLS is established if possible before authentication is attempted. TLS will be established immediately upon connect if indicates that the host requires this (), otherwise the library will use the IMAP STARTTLS command if is in use.

During the authentication part of connecting the will be set (most likely more than once). The value is used to determine what capabilities offered by the server are actually used by the client. It is possible that the will be set during authentication: this indicates that the connected server suggests that we disconnect and try a different server. If authentication is successful then will be set.

After authentication, depending on what the allow;
is enabled (see and ); this sets .
ID (RFC 2971) information is exchanged with the server; this sends (or ) and sets .
Namespace (RFC 2342) information is retrieved from the server; this sets .
A special syntax IMAP LIST command is used to discover the hierarchy delimiter and one personal namespace may be generated using it; this sets .

Normally only one of Namespace and LIST are used during connect, but under some strange circumstances both may be required. (The specific case is when the personal namespaces retrieved from the server do not contain the INBOX.) Once is known is set.
At the end of a successful connect the will be , at the end of a failed connect will be and this method will throw.

Some of the exceptions that might be thrown and why;
The server actively rejected the connection.
The client was able to try credentials from , but they didn't work. If the server explicitly rejected the credentials using one of the , or codes, then will contain the details (otherwise the will be ).
The client was not able to try any credentials from . If the TLS state was to blame for this then will be set to .
While connecting the server either refused to connect or refused to authenticate and suggested that we try a different server instead (see and the contained ).

member.name: M:work.bacome.imapclient.cIMAPClient.ConnectAsync
member.summary: Ansynchronously connects to the using the . May only be called when the instance . Will throw if an authenticated IMAP connection cannot be established.

member.name: M:work.bacome.imapclient.cIMAPClient.Create(work.bacome.imapclient.cMailboxName,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a new mailbox on the connected server.
member.param: The mailbox name to use.
Indicates to the server that you intend to create child mailboxes in the new mailbox.

remarks.para:
Some servers exhibit unusual behaviour when the mailbox name includes 'unusual' characters (e.g. '/' when it isn't the delimiter). 
            Observed behaviours are;
            
            An 
'OK' reply, but the mailbox created has a truncated name.

Some servers exhibit unusual behaviour when is despite this appearing to be in violation of RFC 3501 section 6.3.3. Observed behaviours are;
An 'OK' reply and a mailbox created with the name specified (correct behaviour according to RFC 3501).
A 'NO' reply and no mailbox created.
An 'OK [CANNOT]' reply and no mailbox created.
An 'OK' reply and a mailbox created with the name specified, but the mailbox has the \NoSelect flag set (so the mailbox can't be used to store messages).

member.summary: Ansynchronously creates a new mailbox on the connected server.
member.param: The mailbox name to use.
Indicates to the server that you intend to create child mailboxes in the new mailbox.

member.name: T:work.bacome.imapclient.sStoreFeedbackSummary
member.summary: Contains a summary of store operation feedback.

remarks.para: Each message counts towards ONE of;
Generally + + is the number of definite non-updates.
Generally > 0 indicates that a may be worth trying to get any pending updates from the server (which should convert all the notreflects to expunged or reflects).
remarks.note: After a you should get the summary again to see the effect of any updates sent by the server.
remarks.para: Generally > 0 indicates that a blind store was done so there isn't enough information to say whether the store happened or not.

member.name: F:work.bacome.imapclient.sStoreFeedbackSummary.UpdatedCount
member.summary: The count where an IMAP FETCH response containing the flags for the message was received during the store operation AND the message wasn't mentioned in the RFC 7162 MODIFIED response code of the store operation (=> the message was _likely_ to have been updated by the store).

member.name: F:work.bacome.imapclient.sStoreFeedbackSummary.WasNotUnchangedSinceCount
member.summary: The count where the message was mentioned in the RFC 7162 MODIFIED response code of the store operation (=> _NOT_ updated by the store).

member.name: F:work.bacome.imapclient.sStoreFeedbackSummary.UnknownCount
member.summary: The count where the entry in the message cache for the message can't be found, or where it can be found but it doesn't contain the flags for the message.

member.summary: The count where the flags in the message cache do not reflect the store operation.

member.name: T:work.bacome.imapclient.cMailbox
member.summary: Represents an IMAP mailbox.

remarks.para: Instances of this class are only valid whilst the remains connected. Reconnecting the client will not bring instances back to life.

To interact with messages in a mailbox, IMAP requires that the mailbox be selected - use to select the mailbox. Each IMAP connection (and hence each instance) can have at most one mailbox selected selecting a mailbox automatically un-selects the previously selected mailbox. An instance of this class may be selected and un-selected many times in its lifetime. instances are valid only whilst the mailbox they are in remains selected.

member.name: T:work.bacome.imapclient.cMailboxName
member.summary: Represents an IMAP mailbox name.
member.remarks: IMAP mailbox names have few grammatical restrictions, but may not include the NUL character. IMAP hierarchy delimitiers have few grammatical restrictions, but must be ASCII, and not NUL, CR or LF. Be careful to correctly specify the hierarchy delimiter, it is used in preparing the mailbox name for sending to the server.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cMessage.BodyStructure
member.summary: Gets the IMAP BODYSTRUCTURE of the message.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cMessage.Attachments
member.summary: Gets a list of message attachments. The list may be empty.
member.remarks: If the message cache does not contain the of the message, it will be fetched from the server. The library defines an attachment as a single-part message body-part with a disposition of attachment. If there are alternate versions of an attachment only one of the alternates is included in the list (the first one).

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cMessage.PlainTextSizeInBytes
member.summary: Gets the size in bytes of the plain text of the message. May be zero.
member.remarks: If the message cache does not contain the of the message, it will be fetched from the server. The library defines plain text as being contained in message body-parts with a MIME type of text/plain and without a disposition of 'attachment'. If there are alternate versions of a body-part only one of the alternates is considered to be part of the plain text (the first one). The size returned is the encoded size of the body-parts.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cMessage.References
member.summary: Gets the normalised message-ids from the references header field. May be .
member.remarks: If the message cache does not contain the header field of the message, it will be fetched from the server. Normalised message-ids have the delimiters, quoting, comments and white space removed. Will be if there is no references header field or if the references header field can not be parsed.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cMessage.Importance
member.summary: Gets the importance value from the importance header field. May be .
member.remarks: If the message cache does not contain the header field of the message, it will be fetched from the server. Will be if there is no importance header field or if the importance header field can not be parsed.

member.summary: Returns the plain text of the message.
member.remarks: If the message cache does not contain the of the message, it will be fetched from the server. The library defines plain text as being contained in message body-parts with a MIME type of text/plain and without a disposition of 'attachment'. If there are alternate versions of a body-part only one of the alternates is considered to be part of the plain text (the first one). The required body-parts are fetched from the server and concatented to yield the result. The text returned is the decoded text.

member.name: T:work.bacome.imapclient.cClientIdUTF8
member.summary: An immutable ID (RFC 2971) field/ value dictionary.

remarks.para: ID field names are case insensitive.

This class enforces the limits of RFC 2971;
Field names no longer than 30 bytes.
Values no longer than 1024 bytes.
No more than 30 field/ value pairs.

member.name: T:work.bacome.imapclient.cIdleConfiguration
member.summary: Contains parameters that control the idle feature.

remarks.para: The aim of idling is to keep the client in synch with the server, in particular the client's data about the currently selected mailbox.
A instance can only idle while it .
Idling starts after a configured length of quiet time on the underlying connection (see ).

If is in use then the RFC 2177 IDLE command is used. The IDLE command has to be restarted periodically to avoid the connection being closed due to inactivity - RFC 2177 recommends at least once every 29 minutes (see ).
If is not in use then the library does a periodic poll of the server using IMAP CHECK and/ or NOOP (see ).

The default values are;
2s
20 minutes
60s

member.name: F:work.bacome.imapclient.cIdleConfiguration.StartDelay
member.summary: The length of the quiet time that must pass before idling starts, in milliseconds.

member.name: F:work.bacome.imapclient.cIdleConfiguration.IdleRestartInterval
member.summary: The interval between RFC 2177 IDLE commands, in milliseconds.

member.name: F:work.bacome.imapclient.cIdleConfiguration.PollInterval
member.summary: The interval between polling commands, in milliseconds.

member.name: M:work.bacome.imapclient.cIdleConfiguration.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initialises a new instance with the specified start delay, restart interval and poll interval.
member.param: The length of the quiet time that must pass before idling starts, in milliseconds.
The interval between RFC 2177 IDLE commands, in milliseconds.
The interval between polling commands, in milliseconds.

member.name: T:work.bacome.imapclient.cSASL
member.summary: Represents an object that can participate in the SASL mechanism.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cSASL.MechanismName
member.summary: Gets the SASL mechanism name.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cSASL.TLSRequirement
member.summary: Gets the TSL requirement for the contained details to be used.

member.name: M:work.bacome.imapclient.cSASL.GetAuthentication
member.summary: Returns an object that can participate in the authentication process.
member.remarks: If authentication is successful the library will use to get an object that implements any security layer negotiated as part of the authentication. must return if no security layer was negotiated. The object will be disposed once authentication is complete (upon either of success or failure). Any object obtained will be disposed when the underlying network connection closes.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cSASL.LastAuthentication
member.summary: Gets a reference to the object returned by for use in the last attempt. May be .
member.remarks: This will return if the instance was not used in the last attempt. This property exists for mechanisms that have out of band error reporting (e.g. XOAUTH2) and provides a way for the out of band errors to be passed back to external code. Any object returned will almost certainly have been disposed.

member.name: T:work.bacome.imapclient.cSASLAuthentication
member.summary: Represents an object that can participate in the SASL authentication process.
member.remarks: Instances will be disposed once authentication is complete (upon either of success or failure).

member.name: M:work.bacome.imapclient.cSASLAuthentication.GetResponse(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Byte})
member.summary: Gets the client response to a server challenge.

remarks.para: The library passes the BASE64 decoded challenge to this method and BASE64 encodes the returned response before sending it to the server. If the authentication exchange should be cancelled then this method should return ; the library will then gracefully cancel the exchange with the server.

If is in use then the first challenge passed to this method will be . If the mechanism supports an initial response then the initial response should be returned, otherwise should be returned. If the initial response is 'empty' then a zero length response should be returned, not .

member.name: M:work.bacome.imapclient.cSASLAuthentication.GetSecurity
member.summary: Returns an object that can participate in the SASL security layer process.
member.remarks: This will only be called (and will always be called) after a successful authentication exchange. If no security layer was negotiated through the authentication exchange, must be returned. If an object is returned it will be disposed when the connection closes.

member.name: T:work.bacome.imapclient.cSASLSecurity
member.summary: Represents an object that can participate in the SASL security layer process.
member.remarks: Instances will be disposed when the connection closes.

member.name: M:work.bacome.imapclient.cSASLSecurity.Decode(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Decodes data received from the server.
member.param: The data received from the server.
member.returns: A buffer of decoded data or if decoding cannot be completed until more input arrives.
member.remarks: Input buffers of encoded bytes are delivered to this method as they arrive. Any bytes that cannot be decoded due to there being an 'uneven' number of bytes must be buffered. If there is a decoding error then this method must throw: this will immediately terminate the connection to the server.

member.name: M:work.bacome.imapclient.cSASLSecurity.Encode(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Encodes client data for sending to the server.
member.param: The un-encoded data to be sent.
member.returns: The encoded data to be sent.
member.remarks: If there is a problem encoding the data this method should return (or it may throw), this will immediately terminate the connection to the server.

member.name: T:work.bacome.imapclient.cSASLPlain
member.summary: Contains arguments for use with the IMAP AUTHENTICATE PLAIN command.
member.remarks: RFC 4616 specifies that the authentication-id and password must be at least 1 character long and that they may not include the NUL character.

member.summary: Initialises a new instance with the specified authentication-id, password and TLS requirement. Will throw if the authentication-id or password are not valid.

member.name: T:work.bacome.async.cExclusiveAccess
member.summary: Provides a mechanism to control exclusive access using tokens and blocks.

remarks.para: The granting of exclusive access is done by issuing a token. Exclusive access is released by disposing the token object.
The granting of exclusive access may be blocked by the previous issue of blocks. Several blocks can be on issue at the same time. Blocks are released by disposing the block objects.
Blocks will not be issued while a token is on issue. Tokens will not be issued while blocks are on issue (nor will they be issued while a token is on issue).
Instance sequence numbers (specified in the constructor) can be used by external code to ensure that the program's tokens are requested in a consistent order (to avoid deadlocks).
Each instance of this class is allocated a unique instance number that is used in messages to aid debugging.
This class implements , so you should dispose instances when you are finished with them.

member.name: T:work.bacome.trace.cTrace
member.summary: Provides services for writing trace events with indenting and nested context information.

remarks.para: Instances of this class wrap a and trace messages are written using its services.
remarks.note: The services provided by this class do not support the dynamic addition of trace listeners to the wrapped . The trace messages that will be written by an instance are determined at the time of construction (by inspecting the state of the ).
remarks.para: Trace messages are always written in a context. Context starts at an independent root-context. Sub-contexts can be established within root-contexts and within other sub-contexts. If a new sub-context is created for each call then call stack information can be built and included in the trace.

Context creation itself can result in a trace message (the context-create trace message). Context-create trace messages can be written immediately (as the contexts are created), or they can be written only if, and only when, a non-context-create trace message is written in the context (or a sub-context of the context). This delayed context-create writing can minimise unnecessary and unhelpful tracing, whilst retaining the benefits of tracing the full context when something interesting happens.
remarks.note: If the writing of context-create trace messages is delayed then the generation of the trace message text is also delayed. If there are mutable objects to be included in the trace message text, this can lead to misleading context-create trace messages.
remarks.para:
Tracing can be disabled, either for an instance as a whole or for parts of the context tree. When tracing is disabled contexts are not created and trace messages are not written, so most of the tracing overhead is eliminated. Tracing is disabled under the following circumstances;
The assembly is compiled without the "TRACE" conditional attribute.
There aren't any listeners attached to the wrapped when the instance is constructed.
The wrapped isn't configured to emit messages when the instance is constructed.
The context is used as a root-context.
Root-contexts have a name and a number. The name is programmer assigned, the number is assigned by the class and is unique within the program.

Trace messages are written in a tab delimited form, the tab delimited columns contain;
The defined data.
The date and time that the message was written.
The name and number of the root-context associated with the trace message.
The thread number on which the trace message was written.
The space indented (by a number of spaces equal to the context-depth) trace message.
